Provably Doubly Accelerated Federated Learning:
The First Theoretically Successful Combination of
Local Training and Communication Compression

Laurent Condat11{\!\>}^{1} â€ƒâ€ƒIvan AgarskÃ½2,323{\!\>}^{2,3} â€ƒâ€ƒPeter RichtÃ¡rik11{\!\>}^{1}

Abstract

In federated learning, a large number of users are involved in a global learning task, in a collaborative way. They alternate local computations and two-way communication with a distant orchestrating server. Communication, which can be slow and costly, is the main bottleneck in this setting. To reduce the communication load and therefore accelerate distributed gradient descent, two strategies are popular: 1) communicate less frequently; that is, perform several iterations of local computations between the communication rounds; and 2) communicate compressed information instead of full-dimensional vectors. We propose the first algorithm for distributed optimization and federated learning, which harnesses these two strategies jointly and converges linearly to an exact solution in the strongly convex setting, with a doubly accelerated rate: our algorithm benefits from the two acceleration mechanisms provided by local training and compression, namely a better dependency on the condition number of the functions and on the dimension of the model, respectively.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a novel paradigm for training supervised machine learning models. Initiated a few years ago in several foundational papers (KoneÄnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016a, ; KoneÄnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016b, ; McMahan etÂ al.,, 2017; Bonawitz etÂ al.,, 2017), it has become a rapidly growing interdisciplinary field. The key idea is to exploit the wealth of information stored on edge devices, such as mobile phones, sensors and hospital workstations, to train global models, in a collaborative way, while handling a multitude of challenges, like data privacy concerns (Kairouz etÂ al.,, 2021; Li etÂ al.,, 2020; Wang etÂ al.,, 2021). In contrast to centralized learning in a datacenter, in FL, the parallel computing units have private data stored on each of them and communicate with a distant orchestrating server, which aggregates the information and synchronizes the computations, so that the process reaches a consensus and converges to a globally optimal model. In this framework, communication between the parallel workers and the server, which can take place over the internet or cell phone network, can be slow, costly, and unreliable. Thus, communication dominates the overall time cost of the process and is the main bottleneck to be addressed by the community, before FL can be widely adopted and applied in our daily lives.

The baseline algorithm of distributed Gradient Descent (GD) alternates between two steps: one round of parallel computation of the local function gradients at the current model estimate, and one round of communication of these gradient vectors to the server, which averages them to form the new estimate for the next iteration. To decrease the communication load, two strategies can be used: 1) communicate less frequently, or equivalently do more local computations between successive communication rounds; or 2) compress the communicated vectors. We detail these two strategies in Section 1.3. In this paper, we combine them, within a unified framework for randomized communication, and derive a new algorithm named CompressedScaffnew, with local training and communication compression. It is variance-reduced (Hanzely and RichtÃ¡rik,, 2019; Gorbunov etÂ al., 2020a, ; Gower etÂ al.,, 2020), so that it converges to an exact solution, and provably benefits from the two mechanisms: the convergence rate is doubly accelerated, with a better dependency on the condition number of the functions and on the dimension of the model, in comparison with GD. In the remainder of this section, we formulate the convex optimization problem to solve, we propose a new model to characterize the communication complexity, and we present the state of the art.

1.2 Asymmetric communication regime

Uplink and downlink communication. We call uplink communication (UpCom) the parallel transmission of data from the clients to the server and downlink communication (DownCom) the broadcast of the same message from the server to all clients. UpCom is usually significantly slower than DownCom, just like uploading is slower than downloading on the internet or cell phone network. This can be due to the asymmetry of the service providerâ€™s systems or protocols used on the communication network, or cache memory and aggregation speed constraints of the server, which has to decode and average the large number nğ‘›n of vectors received at the same time during UpCom.

Communication complexity. We measure the UpCom or DownCom complexity as the expected number of communication rounds needed to estimate a solution with Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-accuracy, multiplied by the number of real values sent during a communication round between the server and any client. Thus, the UpCom or DownCom complexity of GD is ğ’ªâ€‹(dâ€‹Îºâ€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1))ğ’ªğ‘‘ğœ…superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\kappa\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}. We leave if for future work to refine this model of counting real numbers, to take into account how sequences of real numbers are quantized into bitstreams, achieving further compression (HorvÃ¡th etÂ al.,, 2022; Albasyoni etÂ al.,, 2020).

A model for the overall communication complexity. Since UpCom is usually slower than DownCom, we propose to measure the total communication (TotalCom) complexity as a weighted sum of the two UpCom and DownCom complexities: we assume that the UpCom cost is 1 (unit of time per transmitted real number), whereas the downCom cost is câˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01c\in[0,1]. Therefore,

TotalCom=UpCom+c.DownCom.formulae-sequenceTotalComUpComğ‘DownCom\mbox{TotalCom}=\mbox{UpCom}+c.\mbox{DownCom}. (2)

A symmetric but unrealistic communication regime corresponds to c=1ğ‘1c=1, whereas ignoring downCom and focusing on UpCom, which is usually the limiting factor, corresponds to c=0ğ‘0c=0. We will provide explicit expressions of the parameters of our algorithm to minimize the TotalCom complexity for any given câˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01c\in[0,1], keeping in mind that realistic settings correspond to small values of cğ‘c. Thus, our model of communication complexity is richer than only considering c=0ğ‘0c=0, as is usually the case.

1.3 Communication efficiency in FL: state of the art

Two approaches come naturally to mind to decrease the communication load: Local Training (LT), which consists in communicating less frequently than at every iteration, and Communication Compression (CC), which consists in sending less than dğ‘‘d floats during every communication round. In this section, we review existing work related to these two strategies.

1.3.1 Local Training (LT)

LT is a conceptually simple and surprisingly powerful communication-acceleration technique. It consists in the clients performing multiple local GD steps instead of only one, between successive communication rounds. This intuitively results in â€œbetterâ€ information being communicated, so that less communication rounds are needed to achieve a given accuracy. As shown by ample empirical evidence, LT is very efficient in practice. It was popularized by the FedAvg algorithm of McMahan etÂ al., (2017), in which LT is a core component, along with other features such as data sampling and partial participation. However, LT was heuristic and no theory was provided in their paper. LT was analyzed in several works, in the homogeneous, or i.i.d.Â data, regime (Haddadpour and Mahdavi,, 2019), and in the heterogeneous regime, which is more representative in FL (Khaled etÂ al.,, 2019, 2020; Stich,, 2019; Woodworth etÂ al.,, 2020; Gorbunov etÂ al.,, 2021; Glasgow etÂ al.,, 2022). It stands out that LT suffers from so-called client drift, which is the fact that the local model obtained by client iğ‘–i after several local GD steps approaches the minimizer of its local cost function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}. The discrepancy between the exact solution xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†x^{\star} of (1) and the approximate solution obtained at convergence of LT was characterized in Malinovsky etÂ al., (2020). This deficiency of LT was corrected in the Scaffold algorithm of Karimireddy etÂ al., (2020) by introducing control variates, which correct for the client drift, so that the algorithm converges linearly to the exact solution. S-Local-GD (Gorbunov etÂ al.,, 2021) and FedLin (Mitra etÂ al.,, 2021) were later proposed, with similar convergence properties. Yet, despite the empirical superiority of these recent algorithms relying on LT, their communication complexity remains the same as vanilla GD, i.e.Â ğ’ªâ€‹(dâ€‹Îºâ€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1))ğ’ªğ‘‘ğœ…superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\kappa\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}.

It is only very recently that Scaffnew was proposed by Mishchenko etÂ al., (2022), a LT algorithm finally achieving proved accelerated communication complexity, with a ğ’ªâ€‹(dâ€‹Îºâ€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1))ğ’ªğ‘‘ğœ…superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\sqrt{\kappa}\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)} rate for both UpCom and DownCom. In Scaffnew, communication is triggered randomly with a small probability pğ‘p at every iteration. Thus, the expected number of local GD steps between two communication rounds is 1/p1ğ‘1/p. By choosing p=Î˜â€‹(1/Îº)ğ‘Î˜1ğœ…p=\Theta(1/\sqrt{\kappa}), the optimal dependency on Îºğœ…\sqrt{\kappa} instead of Îºğœ…\kappa is obtained. Thus, the discovery of Scaffnew is an important milestone, as it provides the first theoretical confirmation that LT is a communication acceleration mechanism. In this paper, we propose to go even further and tackle the multiplicative factor dğ‘‘d in the complexity of Scaffnew.

1.3.2 Communication Compression (CC)

To decrease the communication complexity, a widely used strategy is to make use of (lossy) compression; that is, a possibly randomized mapping ğ’:â„dâ†’â„d:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d} is applied to the vector xğ‘¥x that needs to be communicated, with the property that it is much faster to transfer ğ’â€‹(x)ğ’ğ‘¥\mathcal{C}(x) than the full dğ‘‘d-dimensional vector xğ‘¥x. A popular sparsifying compressor is rand-kğ‘˜k, for some kâˆˆ[d]â‰”{1,â€¦,d}ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘‘â‰”1â€¦ğ‘‘k\in[d]\coloneqq\{1,\ldots,d\}, which multiplies kğ‘˜k elements of xğ‘¥x, chosen uniformly at random, by d/kğ‘‘ğ‘˜d/k, and sets the other ones to zero. If the receiver knows which coordinates have been selected, e.g.Â by running the same pseudo-random generator, only these kğ‘˜k elements of xğ‘¥x are actually communicated, so that the communication complexity is divided by the compression factor d/kğ‘‘ğ‘˜d/k. Another sparsifying compressor is top-kğ‘˜k, which keeps the kğ‘˜k elements of xğ‘¥x with largest absolute values unchanged and sets the other ones to zero. Besides sparsifying compressors (Alistarh etÂ al.,, 2018; Wangni etÂ al.,, 2018; Xu etÂ al.,, 2021), quantization techniques are also widely used, and consist in representing the real elements of xğ‘¥x using fewer bits (Alistarh etÂ al.,, 2017; Wen etÂ al.,, 2017; Albasyoni etÂ al.,, 2020; Dutta etÂ al.,, 2020; Xu etÂ al.,, 2021; HorvÃ¡th etÂ al.,, 2022). Some compressors, like rand-kğ‘˜k, are unbiased; that is, ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’â€‹(x)]=xğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥\mathbb{E}\!\left[\mathcal{C}(x)\right]=x for every xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where ğ”¼â€‹[â‹…]ğ”¼delimited-[]â‹…\mathbb{E}[\cdot] denotes the expectation. On the other hand, compressors like top-kğ‘˜k are biased (Beznosikov etÂ al.,, 2020).

The variance-reduced algorithm DIANA (Mishchenko etÂ al.,, 2019), later extended in several ways (HorvÃ¡th etÂ al.,, 2022; Gorbunov etÂ al., 2020a, ; Condat and RichtÃ¡rik,, 2022), is a major contribution to the field, as it converges linearly with a large class of unbiased compressors. For instance, when the clients use independent rand-111 compressors for UpCom, the UpCom complexity of DIANA is ğ’ªâ€‹((Îºâ€‹(1+dn)+d)â€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1))ğ’ªğœ…1ğ‘‘ğ‘›ğ‘‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}(\kappa(1+\frac{d}{n})+d)\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}. If nğ‘›n is large, this is much better than with GD. Algorithms converging linearly with biased compressors have been proposed recently, like EF21 (RichtÃ¡rik etÂ al.,, 2021; Fatkhullin etÂ al.,, 2021; Condat etÂ al.,, 2022), but the theory is less mature and the acceleration potential not as clear as with unbiased compressors. Our algorithm CompressedScaffnew benefits from CC with specific unbiased compressors, with even more acceleration than DIANA. Also, the focus in DIANA is on UpCom and its DownCom step is the same as in GD, with the full model broadcast at every iteration, so that its TotalCom complexity can be worse than the one of GD. Extensions of DIANA with bidirectional CC, i.e.Â compression in both UpCom and DownCom, have been proposed (Gorbunov etÂ al., 2020b, ; Philippenko and Dieuleveut,, 2020; Liu etÂ al.,, 2020; Condat and RichtÃ¡rik,, 2022), but this does not improve its TotalCom complexity; see also Philippenko and Dieuleveut, (2021) and references therein on bidirectional CC.

2 Goals, challenges, contributions

Now that a breakthrough in the communication barrier of FL has been made with Scaffnew, which reduced Îºğœ…\kappa to Îºğœ…\sqrt{\kappa} in the communication complexity, with a simple LT method and without additional assumptions (e.g., data similarity or stronger smoothness assumptions), our goal is to achieve communication efficiency by further reducing the dependency on the dimension dğ‘‘d, by means of CC. We achieve this goal with our proposed algorithm CompressedScaffnew: as proved in TheoremÂ 4.1, if cğ‘c is small enough, its TotalCom complexity is

ğ’ªâ€‹((dâ€‹Îºn+dâ€‹Îº+d)â€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1)).ğ’ªğ‘‘ğœ…ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğœ…ğ‘‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\left(d\frac{\sqrt{\kappa}}{\sqrt{n}}+\sqrt{d}\sqrt{\kappa}+d\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!.

This double acceleration is all the more remarkable, given that it is very challenging to combine LT and CC. In the strongly convex and heterogeneous case considered here, the methods Qsparse-local-SGD (Basu etÂ al.,, 2020) and FedPAQ (Reisizadeh etÂ al.,, 2020) do not converge linearly. The only linearly converging LT + CC algorithm we are aware of is FedCOMGATE (Haddadpour etÂ al.,, 2021). But its rate is ğ’ªâ€‹(dâ€‹Îºâ€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1))ğ’ªğ‘‘ğœ…superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\kappa\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}, which does not show any acceleration. By contrast, our algorithm is the first, to the best of our knowledge, to exhibit a doubly-accelerated linear rate, by leveraging LT and CC. Random reshuffling, which can be seen as a kind of LT, has been combined with CC in Sadiev etÂ al., (2022). The TotalCom complexity of the various algorithms is reported in TableÂ 1.

We build upon the analysis of Scaffnew to design our new algorithm. In short,

ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—†ğ—‰ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—Œğ–¾ğ–½ğ–²ğ–¼ğ–ºğ–¿ğ–¿ğ—‡ğ–¾ğ—=ğ–¦ğ–£+LTâŸğ–²ğ–¼ğ–ºğ–¿ğ–¿ğ—‡ğ–¾ğ—+CC.ğ–¢ğ—ˆğ—†ğ—‰ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—Œğ–¾ğ–½ğ–²ğ–¼ğ–ºğ–¿ğ–¿ğ—‡ğ–¾ğ—subscriptâŸğ–¦ğ–£LTğ–²ğ–¼ğ–ºğ–¿ğ–¿ğ—‡ğ–¾ğ—CC{\sf\color[rgb]{0.8,0.0,0.0}{CompressedScaffnew}}=\underbrace{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.8,0.0,0.0}{GD}}+\mbox{LT}}_{{\sf\color[rgb]{0.8,0.0,0.0}{Scaffnew}}}{}+\mbox{CC}.

This program of combining LT and CC looks simple at first glance, and it seems we just have to â€˜plugâ€™ compressors into Scaffnew. But this is far from being the case! First, we had to redesign the mechanism behind Scaffnew, which is not ProxSkip (Mishchenko etÂ al.,, 2022) any more, but a new algorithm (Algorithm 2 in the Appendix) with two, instead of one, randomization mechanisms for managing the model estimates and the control variates. Both mechanisms combine probabilistic communication and compression with a random mask, but in different ways. If there is no compression, the two mechanisms coincide, since there is only one source of randomness, which is the coin flip to trigger communication, and CompressedScaffnew reverts to Scaffnew, hence its name. Second, our approach relies on a dedicated design of the compressors, so that the messages sent by the different clients complement each other, to keep a tight control of the variance after aggregation.

We want to stress that our goal is to deepen our theoretical understanding and to reveal the potential of the two LT and CC mechanisms, which are intuitive, effective, and widely used in practice. Thus, GD is at the core of our approach, and CompressedScaffnew reverts to GD if there is no compression and pğ‘p, the probability of communication, is one. There are certainly other ways to design communication-efficient algorithms, and Nesterov acceleration comes to our mind (Nesterov,, 2004): replacing GD by accelerated GD also yields Îºğœ…\sqrt{\kappa} instead of Îºğœ…\kappa in the complexity. Pursuing this path is somehow orthogonal to our approach, which, again, is to combine and get the best of LT and CC, not to get the best possible complexity per se.

3 Proposed algorithm CompressedScaffnew

The proposed algorithm CompressedScaffnew is shown as Algorithm 1. At every iteration tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0, every client iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n] performs a gradient descent step with respect to its private cost fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}, evaluated at its local model xitsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡x_{i}^{t}, with a correction term by its control variate hitsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘¡h_{i}^{t}. This yields a prediction x^itsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡\hat{x}_{i}^{t} of the updated local model. Then a random coin flip is made, to decide whether communication occurs or not. Communication occurs with probability pâˆˆ(0,1]ğ‘01p\in(0,1], with pğ‘p typically small. If there is no communication, xit+1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡1x_{i}^{t+1} is simply set as x^itsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡\hat{x}_{i}^{t} and hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} is unchanged. If communication occurs, every client sends a compressed version of x^itsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡\hat{x}_{i}^{t}; that is, it sends only a few of its elements, selected randomly according to the rule explained in FigureÂ 1 and known by both the clients and the server (for decoding). The server aggregates the received vectors and forms xÂ¯tsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\bar{x}^{t}, which is broadcast to all clients. They all resume with this fresh estimate of the solution. Every client updates its control variates hisubscriptâ„ğ‘–h_{i} by modifying only the coordinates which have been involved in the communication process; that is, for which qitsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡q_{i}^{t} has a one. Indeed, the other coordinates of x^itsuperscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡\hat{x}_{i}^{t} have not participated to the formation of xÂ¯tsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\bar{x}^{t}, so the received vector xÂ¯tsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\bar{x}^{t} does not contain information relevant to update hitsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘¡h_{i}^{t} at these coordinates.

The probability pâˆˆ(0,1]ğ‘01p\in(0,1] of communication controls the amount of LT, since the expected number of local GD steps between two successive communication rounds is 1/p1ğ‘1/p. If p=1ğ‘1p=1, communication happens at every iteration and LT is disabled. The sparsity index sâˆˆ{2,â€¦,n}ğ‘ 2â€¦ğ‘›s\in\{2,\ldots,n\} controls the amount of compression: the lower sğ‘ s, the more compression. If s=nğ‘ ğ‘›s=n and Î·=1ğœ‚1\eta=1, there is no compression and ğ’itâ€‹(v)=vsubscriptsuperscriptğ’ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘£\mathcal{C}^{t}_{i}(v)=v for any vğ‘£v; then CompressedScaffnew reverts to Scaffnew.

Our main result, stating linear convergence of CompressedScaffnew to the exact solution xâ‹†superscriptğ‘¥â‹†x^{\star} of (1), is the following:

Theorem 3.1.

In CompressedScaffnew, suppose that

3.1 Iteration complexity

CompressedScaffnew has the same iteration complexity as GD, with rate Ïâ™¯â‰”max(1âˆ’Î³Î¼,Î³Lâˆ’1)2\rho^{\sharp}\coloneqq\max(1-\gamma\mu,\gamma L-1)^{2}, as long as pğ‘p and sğ‘ s are large enough to have

1âˆ’p2â€‹Î·â€‹sâˆ’1nâˆ’1â‰¤Ïâ™¯.1superscriptğ‘2ğœ‚ğ‘ 1ğ‘›1superscriptğœŒâ™¯1-p^{2}\eta\frac{s-1}{n-1}\leq\rho^{\sharp}.

This is remarkable: compression during aggregation with p<1ğ‘1p<1 and s<nğ‘ ğ‘›s<n does not harm convergence at all, until some threshold. This is in contrast with other algorithms with CC, like DIANA, where even a small amount of compression worsens the worst-case complexity.

For any sâ‰¥2ğ‘ 2s\geq 2, pâˆˆ(0,1]ğ‘01p\in(0,1], Î³=Î˜â€‹(1L)ğ›¾Î˜1ğ¿\gamma=\Theta(\frac{1}{L}), and fixed Î·âˆˆ(0,1]ğœ‚01\eta\in(0,1], the asymptotic iteration complexity of CompressedScaffnew to reach Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-accuracy, i.e. ğ”¼â€‹[Î¨t]â‰¤Ïµğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptÎ¨ğ‘¡italic-Ïµ\mathbb{E}\!\left[\Psi^{t}\right]\leq\epsilon, is

Thus, by choosing

3.2 Convergence in the convex case

In this section only, we remove the hypothesis of strong convexity: the functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} are just assumed to be convex and Lğ¿L-smooth, and we suppose that a solution xâ‹†âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptğ‘¥â‹†superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} to (1) exists. Theorem 3.3.

In CompressedScaffnew, suppose that

0<Î³<2Land0<Î·<nâ€‹(sâˆ’1)sâ€‹(nâˆ’1)âˆˆ(12,1].formulae-sequence0ğ›¾2ğ¿and0ğœ‚ğ‘›ğ‘ 1ğ‘ ğ‘›11210<\gamma<\frac{2}{L}\quad\mbox{and}\quad 0<\eta<\frac{n(s-1)}{s(n-1)}\in\left(\frac{1}{2},1\right]. (11)

For every i=1,â€¦,nğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘›i=1,\ldots,n and Tâ‰¥0ğ‘‡0T\geq 0, we define

x~iTâ‰”1T+1â€‹âˆ‘t=0Txit.â‰”superscriptsubscript~ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘‡1ğ‘‡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¡\tilde{x}_{i}^{T}\coloneqq\frac{1}{T+1}\sum_{t=0}^{T}x_{i}^{t}. (12)

Then

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(x~iT)â€–2]=ğ’ªâ€‹(1T)ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptsubscript~ğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘‡2ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathbb{E}\!\left[\left\|\nabla f(\tilde{x}_{i}^{T})\right\|^{2}\right]=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{T}\right) (13)

(an explicit upper bound is given in the proof).

4 Communication complexity

For any sâ‰¥2ğ‘ 2s\geq 2, pâˆˆ(0,1]ğ‘01p\in(0,1], Î³=Î˜â€‹(1L)ğ›¾Î˜1ğ¿\gamma=\Theta(\frac{1}{L}), and fixed Î·âˆˆ(0,1]ğœ‚01\eta\in(0,1], the asymptotic iteration complexity of CompressedScaffnew is given in (8). Communication occurs at every iteration with probability pğ‘p, and during every communication round, DownCom consists in broadcasting the full dğ‘‘d-dimensional vector xÂ¯tsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\bar{x}^{t}, whereas in UpCom, compression is effective and the number of real values sent in parallel by the clients is equal to the number of ones per column in the sampling pattern qğ‘q, which is âŒˆsâ€‹dnâŒ‰â‰¥1ğ‘ ğ‘‘ğ‘›1\lceil\frac{sd}{n}\rceil\geq 1. Hence, the communication complexities are:

DownCom:ğ’ªâ€‹(pâ€‹dâ€‹(Îº+nsâ€‹p2)â€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1)),DownCom:ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘‘ğœ…ğ‘›ğ‘ superscriptğ‘2superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mbox{DownCom:}\quad\mathcal{O}\left(pd\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{sp^{2}}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!,
UpCom:ğ’ªâ€‹(pâ€‹(sâ€‹dn+1)â€‹(Îº+nsâ€‹p2)â€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1)).UpCom:ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘‘ğ‘›1ğœ…ğ‘›ğ‘ superscriptğ‘2superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mbox{UpCom:}\quad\mathcal{O}\left(p\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1\right)\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{sp^{2}}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!.
TotalCom:ğ’ªâ€‹(pâ€‹(sâ€‹dn+1+câ€‹d)â€‹(Îº+nsâ€‹p2)â€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1)).TotalCom:ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘‘ğ‘›1ğ‘ğ‘‘ğœ…ğ‘›ğ‘ superscriptğ‘2superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mbox{TotalCom:}\ \ \mathcal{O}\left(p\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1+cd\right)\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{sp^{2}}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!.

For a given sğ‘ s, the best choice for pğ‘p, for both DownCom and UpCom, is given in (9), or more generally (10), for which

ğ’ªâ€‹(pâ€‹(Îº+nsâ€‹p2))=ğ’ªâ€‹(nâ€‹Îºs+ns)ğ’ªğ‘ğœ…ğ‘›ğ‘ superscriptğ‘2ğ’ªğ‘›ğœ…ğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘ \mathcal{O}\left(p\left(\kappa+\frac{n}{sp^{2}}\right)\right)=\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{\frac{n\kappa}{s}}+\frac{n}{s}\right)

and the TotalCom complexity is

TotalCom:ğ’ªâ€‹((nâ€‹Îºs+ns)â€‹(sâ€‹dn+1+câ€‹d)â€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1)).TotalCom:ğ’ªğ‘›ğœ…ğ‘ ğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘‘ğ‘›1ğ‘ğ‘‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mbox{TotalCom:}\ \ \mathcal{O}\left(\!\left(\sqrt{\frac{n\kappa}{s}}+\frac{n}{s}\right)\!\left(\frac{sd}{n}+1+cd\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\!\right)\!.

We see the first acceleration effect due to LT: with a suitable p<1ğ‘1p<1, the communication complexity only depends on Îºğœ…\sqrt{\kappa}, not Îºğœ…\kappa, whatever the compression level sğ‘ s. Without compression, i.e.Â s=nğ‘ ğ‘›s=n, CompressedScaffnew reverts to Scaffnew, with TotalCom complexity ğ’ªâ€‹(dâ€‹Îºâ€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1))ğ’ªğ‘‘ğœ…superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\big{(}d\sqrt{\kappa}\log(\epsilon^{-1})\big{)}. We can now set sğ‘ s to further accelerate the algorithm, by minimizing the TotalCom complexity:

Theorem 4.1.

In CompressedScaffnew, suppose that (3) holds, with Î·ğœ‚\eta fixed and Î³=Î˜â€‹(1L)ğ›¾Î˜1ğ¿\gamma=\Theta(\frac{1}{L}), that pğ‘p satisfies (10) and that

s=maxâ¡(2,âŒŠndâŒ‹,âŒŠcâ€‹nâŒ‹).ğ‘ 2ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘›s=\max\left(2,\left\lfloor\frac{n}{d}\right\rfloor,\lfloor cn\rfloor\right). (14)

Then the TotalCom complexity of CompressedScaffnew is

ğ’ªâ€‹((dâ€‹Îºn+dâ€‹Îº+d+câ€‹dâ€‹Îº)â€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1)).ğ’ªğ‘‘ğœ…ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğœ…ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğœ…superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\left(d\frac{\sqrt{\kappa}}{\sqrt{n}}+\sqrt{d}\sqrt{\kappa}+d+\sqrt{c}\,d\sqrt{\kappa}\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!. (15)

Hence, as long as câ‰¤maxâ¡(2n,1d,1Îº)ğ‘2ğ‘›1ğ‘‘1ğœ…c\leq\max(\frac{2}{n},\frac{1}{d},\frac{1}{\kappa}), there is no difference with the case c=0ğ‘0c=0, in which we only focus on UpCom, and the TotalCom complexity is

ğ’ªâ€‹((dâ€‹Îºn+dâ€‹Îº+d)â€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1)).ğ’ªğ‘‘ğœ…ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğœ…ğ‘‘superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\!\left(\left(d\frac{\sqrt{\kappa}}{\sqrt{n}}+\sqrt{d}\sqrt{\kappa}+d\right)\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\right)\!.

On the other hand, if câ‰¥maxâ¡(2n,1d,1Îº)ğ‘2ğ‘›1ğ‘‘1ğœ…c\geq\max(\frac{2}{n},\frac{1}{d},\frac{1}{\kappa}), the complexity increases and becomes

ğ’ªâ€‹(câ€‹dâ€‹Îºâ€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1)),ğ’ªğ‘ğ‘‘ğœ…superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\Big{(}\sqrt{c}\,d\sqrt{\kappa}\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\Big{)},

but compression remains operational and effective with the cğ‘\sqrt{c} factor. It is only when c=1ğ‘1c=1 that s=nğ‘ ğ‘›s=n, i.e.Â there is no compression and CompressedScaffnew reverts to Scaffnew, and that the Upcom, DownCom and TotalCom complexities all become

ğ’ªâ€‹(dâ€‹Îºâ€‹logâ¡(Ïµâˆ’1)).ğ’ªğ‘‘ğœ…superscriptitalic-Ïµ1\mathcal{O}\Big{(}d\sqrt{\kappa}\log\!\big{(}\epsilon^{-1}\big{)}\Big{)}.

In any case, for every câˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01c\in[0,1], CompressedScaffnew is faster than Scaffnew.

We have reported in TableÂ 1 the TotalCom complexity for several algorithms, and to the best of our knowledge, CompressedScaffnew improves upon all known algorithms, which use either LT or CC on top of GD.

5 Experiments

Carrying out large-scale experiments is beyond the scope of this work, which limits itself to foundational algorithmic and theoretical properties of above-mentioned algorithms. Nevertheless, we illustrate and confirm our results on a practical logistic regression problem.

The global loss function is

fâ€‹(x)=1Mâ€‹âˆ‘m=1Mlogâ¡(1+expâ¡(âˆ’bmâ€‹amâŠ¤â€‹x))+Î¼2â€‹â€–xâ€–2,ğ‘“ğ‘¥1ğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘€1subscriptğ‘ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘štopğ‘¥ğœ‡2superscriptnormğ‘¥2f(x)=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^{M}\log(1+\exp(-b_{m}a_{m}^{\top}x))+\frac{\mu}{2}\|x\|^{2}, (16)

where the amâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘a_{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and bmâˆˆ{âˆ’1,1}subscriptğ‘ğ‘š11b_{m}\in\{-1,1\} are data samples and Mğ‘€M is their total number. The function fğ‘“f in (16) is split into nğ‘›n functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} (the remainder of Mğ‘€M divided by nğ‘›n samples is discarded). The strong convexity parameter Î¼ğœ‡\mu is set to 0.003â€‹L00.003subscriptğ¿00.003L_{0} in FigureÂ 2 and 10âˆ’6â€‹L0superscript106subscriptğ¿010^{-6}L_{0} in FigureÂ 3, where L0subscriptğ¿0L_{0} is the smoothness constant without the Î¼2â€‹â€–xâ€–2ğœ‡2superscriptnormğ‘¥2\frac{\mu}{2}\|x\|^{2} term (so that L=L0+Î¼)L=L_{0}+\mu). We consider the case where the number of clients is larger than the model dimension (n>dğ‘›ğ‘‘n>d) and vice versa. For this, we use the â€˜w8aâ€™ and â€˜real-simâ€™ datasets from the classical LIBSVM libraryÂ (Chang and Lin,, 2011). For each of them, we consider the two cases c=0ğ‘0c=0 and c=0.2ğ‘0.2c=0.2.

We measure the convergence error fâ€‹(x)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†f(x)-f(x^{\star}) with respect to the TotalCom amount of communication, where xğ‘¥x is xtsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x^{t} for GD and xÂ¯tsuperscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘¡\bar{x}^{t} when communication occurs for CompressedScaffnew and Scaffnew. The objective gap fâ€‹(x)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†f(x)-f(x^{\star}) is a fair way to compare different algorithms and, since fğ‘“f is Lğ¿L-smooth, fâ€‹(x)âˆ’fâ€‹(xâ‹†)â‰¤L2â€‹â€–xâˆ’xâ‹†â€–2ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥â‹†ğ¿2superscriptnormğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥â‹†2f(x)-f(x^{\star})\leq\frac{L}{2}\|x-x^{\star}\|^{2} for any xğ‘¥x, so that it is guaranteed to converge linearly with the same rate as Î¨Î¨\Psi in TheoremÂ 3.1.

The stepsize Î³=2L+Î¼ğ›¾2ğ¿ğœ‡\gamma=\frac{2}{L+\mu} is used in all algorithms. The probability pğ‘p is set to 1Îº1ğœ…\frac{1}{\sqrt{\kappa}} for Scaffnew and minâ¡(nsâ€‹Îº,1)ğ‘›ğ‘ ğœ…1\min(\sqrt{\frac{n}{s\kappa}},1) for CompressedScaffnew, with sğ‘ s and Î·ğœ‚\eta set according to Equations (14) and (7), respectively. x0superscriptğ‘¥0x^{0} and the hi0superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–0h_{i}^{0} are all set to zero vectors.

The results are shown in Figures 2 and 3. The algorithms converge linearly, and CompressedScaffnew is faster than Scaffnew, as expected. This confirms that the proposed compression technique is effective. The speedup of CompressedScaffnew over Scaffnew is higher for c=0ğ‘0c=0 than for c=0.2ğ‘0.2c=0.2. This is also expected, since when cğ‘c increases, there is less compression and the two algorithms become more similar; they are the same, without compression, when c=1ğ‘1c=1.

6 Conclusion

Our proposed algorithm CompressedScaffnew is the first to provably benefit from the two combined acceleration mechanisms of Local Training (LT) and Communication Compression (CC). Moreover, this is achieved not only for uplink communication, but for our more comprehensive model of total communication. Our theoretical achievements are confirmed in practice. This pushes the boundary of our understanding of LT and CC to a new level. Among venues for future work, we can mention replacing the true gradients âˆ‡fiâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\nabla f_{i} by stochastic estimates, a feature present in several algorithms like Scaffnew (Malinovsky etÂ al.,, 2022) and FedCOMGATE (Haddadpour etÂ al.,, 2021), or allowing for partial participation and for a larger class of possibly biased compressors, including quantization. The nonconvex case should also be studied (Karimireddy etÂ al.,, 2021; Das etÂ al.,, 2022).

Appendix C Proof of TheoremÂ 3.3
